revision.text:
'''Actual notice''' is a [[law]] term, used most frequently in [[civil procedure]]. It is notice (usually to a defendant in a civil proceeding) delivered in such a way as to give legally sufficient assurance that actual knowledge of the matter has been conveyed to the recipient.<ref>[http://dictionary.law.com/default2.asp?selected=2320 Law.com Dictionary]</ref> [[Service of process|Personal service]], that is, physically handing something to an individual, is usually considered the least-disputable method of giving actual notice.
Actual notice may be contrasted with [[constructive notice]], which is a way of giving notice that may not immediately bring the matter to the attention of the individual that is intended to receive the notice. Constructive notice includes, among other methods, service on an agent or family member, service by posting (on the front door), and service by publication (as in a newspaper).
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Actual Notice}} [[Category:Legal terminology]] [[Category:Civil procedure]]
{{law-term-stub}}

revision.comment: /* Allotone */ is
revision.text:
{{for|the term for someone whose native language is not French or English, typically used in Canada|Allophone (Canada)}} [[File:Phoneme-allophone-determination-chart.svg|thumb|A simplified procedure to determine whether two sounds represent the same or different phonemes. The cases on the extreme left and the extreme right are those in which the sounds are allophones.]] In [[phonology]], an '''allophone''' ({{IPAc-en|Àà|√¶|l|…ô|f|o ä|n}}; from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] {{lang|grc|·ºÑŒªŒªŒøœÇ}}, ''√°llos'', "other" and {{lang|grc|œÜœâŒΩŒÆ}}, ''ph≈çnƒì'', "voice, sound") is one of a set of multiple possible spoken sounds, or ''[[phone (phonetics)|phones]]'', or signs used to pronounce a single [[phoneme]] in a particular language.<ref name="ref00qacid">{{Citation | title=Structure of Language and Its Mathematical Aspects: Proceedings of symposia in applied mathematics | author=R. Jakobson | publisher=AMS Bookstore, 1980 | isbn=978-0-8218-1312-6 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ou_zOzU9wEwC | quote=''...An allophone is the set of phones contained in the intersection of a maximal set of phonetically similar phones and a primary phonetically related set of phones....''}}</ref> For example, {{IPAblink|t}} (as in ''stop'' {{IPA|[st…ëp]}}) and {{IPAblink|…æ}} (as in ''Letter {{IPA|[Àà…´…õ…æ…ö]}}'') are allophones for the phoneme {{IPA|/t/}} in [[English language|English]], while these two are considered to be different phonemes in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]. On the other hand {{IPAblink|d}} (as in ''dolor'' {{IPA|[doÃûÀàloÃûr]}}) and {{IPAblink|√∞}} (as in ''nada'' {{IPA|[Ààna√∞a]}}) are allophones for the phoneme {{IPA|/d/}} in Spanish, while these two are considered to be different phonemes in English.
The specific allophone selected in a given situation is often predictable from the phonetic context, with such allophones being called '''positional variants''', but some allophones occur in [[free variation]]. Replacing a sound by another allophone of the same phoneme usually does not change the meaning of a word, but the result may sound non-native or even unintelligible.
Native speakers of a given language perceive one phoneme in the language as a single distinctive sound and are "both unaware of and even shocked by" the allophone variations that are used to pronounce single phonemes.<ref name="ref89rahec">{{Citation | title=Linguistics and Phonetics | author=B.D. Sharma | publisher=Anmol Publications Pvt. Ltd., 2005 | isbn=978-81-261-2120-5 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rDs8sJ5snrUC | quote=''... The ordinary native speaker is, in fact, often unaware of the allophonic variations of his phonemes ...''}}</ref><ref name="ref06hozep">{{Citation | title=Phonology as human behavior: theoretical implications and clinical applications | author=Y. Tobin | publisher=Duke University Press, 1997 | isbn=978-0-8223-1822-4 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NmBYJdTJjKkC | quote=''...always found that native speakers are clearly aware of the phonemes of their language but are both unaware of and even shocked by the plethora of allophones and the minutiae needed to distinguish between them....''}}</ref>
==History of concept== The term "allophone" was coined by [[Benjamin Lee Whorf]] in the 1940s. In doing so, he placed a cornerstone in consolidating early [[phoneme]] theory.<ref>{{cite book|last=Lee|first=Penny|year=1996|title=The Whorf Theory Complex ‚Äî A Critical Reconstruction|publisher=John Benjamins | ref = harv |pages=46, 88}}</ref> The term was popularized by [[George L. Trager]] and [[Bernard Bloch (linguist)|Bernard Bloch]] in a 1941 paper on English phonology<ref>{{cite journal|last=Trager|first=George L.|title=The Systematization of the Whorf Hypothesis|journal=Anthropological Linguistics|volume= 1|issue=1|publisher=Operational Models in Synchronic Linguistics: A Symposium Presented at the 1958 Meetings of the American Anthropological Association|year= 1959|pages=31‚Äì35 |jstor=30022173 | ref = harv }}</ref> and went on to become part of standard usage within the American structuralist tradition.<ref>{{cite book|first=Dell H. |last=Hymes|first2=John G. |last2=Fought|title=American Structuralism|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|year= 1981|ref=harv|page=99}}</ref>
==Complementary and free-variant allophones and assimilation== Whenever a user's speech is vocalized for a given phoneme, it is slightly different from other utterances, even for the same speaker. That has led to some debate over how real and how universal phonemes really are (see [[phoneme]] for details). Only some of the variation is significant, by being detectable or perceivable, to speakers.
There are two types of allophones, based on whether a phoneme must be pronounced using a specific allophone in a specific situation or whether the speaker has the unconscious freedom to choose the allophone that is used.
If a specific allophone from a set of allophones that correspond to a phoneme must be selected in a given context, and using a different allophone for a phoneme would cause confusion or make the speaker sound non-native, the allophones are said to be ''complementary''. The allophones then complement each other, and one of them is not used in a situation in which the usage of another is standard. For complementary allophones, each allophone is used in a specific phonetic context and may be involved in a [[phonology|phonological]] process.<ref name="ref47qoref">{{Citation | title=English L2 reading: getting to the bottom | author=Barbara M. Birch | publisher=Psychology Press, 2002 | isbn=978-0-8058-3899-2 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kiHSOxn0zX4C | quote=''...When the occurrence of one allophone is predictable when compared to the other, as in this case, we call this complementary distribution. Complementary distribution means that the allophones are 'distributed' as complements....''}}</ref>
In other cases, the speaker can freely select from ''[[free variation|free variant]]'' allophones on personal habit or preference.
Another example of an allophone is [[assimilation (phonology)|assimilation]], in which a phoneme is to sound more like another phoneme. One example of assimilation is [[consonant voicing and devoicing]], in which voiceless consonants are voiced before and after voiced consonants, and voiced consonants are devoiced before and after voiceless consonants.
==Allotone== An '''allotone''' is a [[tone (linguistics)|tonic]] allophone, such as the [[neutral tone]] in [[Standard Mandarin]].
== Examples ==
=== English === {{main|English phonology#Allophones of consonants|English phonology#Allophones of vowels}}
There are many allophonic processes in English: lack of plosion, nasal plosion, partial devoicing of sonorants, complete devoicing of sonorants, partial devoicing of obstruents, lengthening and shortening vowels, and retraction.
* [[Aspirated consonant|Aspiration]]: In English, a voiceless plosive {{IPA|/p, t, k/}} is aspirated (has a string explosion of breath) if it is at the beginning of the first or a stressed syllable in a word. For example, {{IPA|[p ∞]}} as in ''pin'' and {{IPA|[p]}} as in ''spin'' are allophones for the phoneme {{IPA|/p/}} because they cannot distinguish words (in fact, they occur in [[complementary distribution]]). English-speakers treat them as the same sound, but they are different: the first is aspirated and the second is [[unaspirated]] (plain). Many languages [[Aspirated consonant#Usage patterns|treat the two phones differently]]. * Nasal plosion ‚Äì In English, a plosive ({{IPA|/p, t, k, b, d, …°/}}) has nasal plosion if it is followed by a nasal, whether within a word or across a word boundary. * Partial devoicing of [[sonorant]]s: In English, sonorants ({{IPA|/j, w, l, r, m, n, ≈ã/}}) are partially devoiced after a voiceless sound in the same syllable. * Complete devoicing of sonorants: In English, a sonorant is completely devoiced after an aspirated plosive ({{IPA|/p, t, k/}}). * Partial devoicing of [[obstruent]]s: In English, a voiced obstruent is partially devoiced next to a pause or next to a voiceless sound within a word or across a word boundary. * Retraction: In English, {{IPA|/t, d, n, l/}} are [[Retracted (phonetics)|retracted]] before {{IPA|/r/}}.
Because the choice among allophones is seldom under conscious control, few people realize their existence. English-speakers may be unaware of the differences among six allophones of the phoneme {{IPA|/t/}}: unreleased {{IPA|[ tÃö]}} as in ''cat'', aspirated {{IPA|[t ∞]}} as in ''top'', glottalized {{IPA|[ î]}} as in ''button'', flapped {{IPA|[…æ]}} as in [[American English]] ''water'', nasalized flapped as in ''winter'', and none of the above {{IPA|[t]}} as in ''stop''. However, they may become aware of the differences if, for example, they contrast the pronunciations of the following words:
*''Night rate'': unreleased {{IPA|[Ààn å…™tÃö.…π ∑e…™tÃö]}} (without a [[word space]] between {{IPA|.}} and {{IPA|…π}}) *''Nitrate'': aspirated {{IPA|[Ààna…™.t ∞…πÃ•e…™tÃö]}} or retracted {{IPA|[Ààna…™.t É…π ∑e…™tÃö]}}
A flame that is held before the lips while those words are spoken flickers more for the aspirated ''nitrate'' than for the unaspirated ''night rate.'' The difference can also be felt by holding the hand in front of the lips. For a [[Mandarin Chinese|Mandarin]]-speaker, for whom {{IPA|/t/}} and {{IPA|/t ∞/}} are separate phonemes, the English distinction is much more obvious than for an English-speaker, who has learned since childhood to ignore the distinction.
Allophones of English {{IPA|/l/}} may be noticed if the 'light' {{IPA|[l]}} of ''leaf'' {{IPA|[ÀàliÀêf]}} is contrasted with the 'dark' {{IPA|[…´]}} of ''feel'' {{IPA|[ÀàfiÀê…´]}}. Again, the difference is much more obvious to a [[Turkish language|Turkish]]-speaker, for whom {{IPA|/l/}} and {{IPA|/…´/}} are separate phonemes, than to an English speaker, for whom they are allophones of a single phoneme.
===Other languages=== There are many examples for allophones in languages other than English. Typically, languages with a small phoneme inventory allow for quite a lot of allophonic variation: examples are [[Hawaiian language#Consonants|Hawaiian]] and [[Toki Pona#Allophony|Toki Pona]]. Here are some examples (the links of language names go to the specific article or subsection on the phenomenon): * Consonant allophones **[[Consonant voicing and devoicing#Final devoicing|Final devoicing]] particularly [[final-obstruent devoicing]]: [[Arapaho language#Allophony|Arapaho]], [[Consonant voicing and devoicing#English|English]], [[Nahuatl#Allophony|Nahuatl]], and many others ** [[Consonant voicing and devoicing#Sound change|Voicing of initial letter]] ** [[Consonant voicing and devoicing#Voicing assimilation|Anticipatory assimilation]] ** Aspiration changes: [[Algonquin language#Aspiration and allophony|Algonquin]] <!-- also Arapaho_language#Allophony, Xavante_language#Allophony, ... --> ** Frication between vowels: [[Dahalo language#Allophony|Dahalo]] ** [[Lenition]]: [[Manx language#Consonants|Manx]] ** Voicing of clicks: [[Dahalo language#Allophony|Dahalo]] <!-- from here on sorted alphabetically --> ** Allophones for /b/: [[Arapaho language#Allophony|Arapaho]], [[Xavante language#Allophony|Xavante]] ** Allophones for /d/: [[Xavante language#Allophony|Xavante]] ** Allophones for /f/: [[Bengali phonology#Allophony|Bengali]] ** Allophones for /j/: [[Xavante language#Allophony|Xavante]] ** Allophones for /k/: [[Manam language#Allophony|Manam]] ** Allophones for /p ∞/: [[Garhwali language#Allophony|Garhwali]] **[g] and [q] as allophones: a number of [[Varieties of Arabic|Arabic dialects]] ** [l] and [n] as allophones: Some dialects of [[Hawaiian language#Consonants|Hawaiian]] ** Allophones for /n/ *** [≈ã]: [[Finnish language#Phonology|Finnish]] and many more. *** wide range of variation in [[Japanese phonology#The moraic nasal /…¥/|Japanese]] (as [[archiphoneme]] /N/) ** Allophones for /r/: [[Xavante language#Allophony|Xavante]] ** Allophones for /…Ω/: [[Bengali phonology#Allophony|Bengali]] ** Allophones for /s/: [[Bengali phonology#Allophony|Bengali]], [[Taos phonology#Consonant phonetics and allophony|Taos]] ** [t] and [k] as allophones: [[Hawaiian language#Consonants|Hawaiian]] ** Allophones for /w/: *** [v] and [w]: [[Hindustani phonology#Allophony of %5Bv%5D and %5Bw%5D|Hindustani]], [[Hawaiian language#Consonants|Hawaiian]] *** fricative [Œ≤] before unrounded vowels: [[O'odham language#Allophony and distribution|O'odham]] ** Allophones for /z/: [[Bengali phonology#Allophony|Bengali]] * Vowel allophones ** [e] and [o] are allophones of /i/ and /u/ in closed final syllables in [[Malay language|Malay]] and […™] and [ ä] are allophones of /i/ and /u/ in [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]]. **[<nowiki/>[[Close central rounded vowel| â]], [[Near-close back rounded vowel| ä]],<nowiki/> [[oÃû]], <nowiki/>[[Close-mid back rounded vowel|o]]] as all<nowiki/>ophones for short /u/, and [<nowiki/>[[Close central unrounded vowel|…®]], <nowiki/>[[Near-close front unrounded vowel|…™]], eÃû<nowiki/>,<nowiki/> [[Close-mid front unrounded vowel|e]]] a<nowiki/>s alloph<nowiki/>ones f<nowiki/>or short /i/ in various [[Varieties of Arabic|Arabic dialects]] (long /uÀê/, /oÀê/, /iÀê/, /eÀê/ are separate phonemes in most Arabic dialects). **[[Polish phonology#Vowel allophony|Polish]] **[[Russian phonology#Allophony|Russian]] ** Allophones for /i/, /a/ and /u/: [[Nux√°lk language#Allophony|Nux√°lk]] * Vowel/consonant allophones ** Vowels become glides in diphthongs: [[Manam language#Allophony|Manam]] <!-- The above list has been created from the results of https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special%3ASearch&profile=advanced&search=allophony&fulltext=Search&ns0=1&ns9=1&ns11=1&profile=advanced. Not included yet: [[Quenya#Morphophonemics_and_allophony]], . Also the following has relevance here: [[Free variation]]. -->
== Representing a phoneme with an allophone == Since phonemes are abstractions of speech sounds, not the sounds themselves, they have no direct [[phonetic transcription]]. When they are realized without much allophonic variation, a simple [[broad transcription]] is used. However, when there are complementary allophones of a phoneme, the allophony becomes significant and things then become more complicated. Often, if only one of the allophones is simple to transcribe, in the sense of not requiring diacritics, that representation is chosen for the phoneme.
However, there may be several such allophones, or the linguist may prefer greater precision than that allows. In such cases, a common convention is to use the "elsewhere condition" to decide the allophone that stands for the phoneme. The "elsewhere" allophone is the one that remains once the conditions for the others are described by phonological rules.
For example, English has both oral and nasal allophones of its vowels. The pattern is that vowels are nasal only before a nasal consonant in the same syllable; elsewhere, they are oral. Therefore, by the "elsewhere" convention, the oral allophones are considered basic, and nasal vowels in English are considered to be allophones of oral phonemes.
In other cases, an allophone may be chosen to represent its phoneme because it is more common in the languages of the world than the other allophones, because it reflects the historical origin of the phoneme, or because it gives a more balanced look to a chart of the phonemic inventory.
An alternative, which is commonly used for [[archiphoneme]]s, is to use a capital letter, such as /N/ for [m], [n], [≈ã].
In rare cases, a linguist may represent phonemes with abstract symbols, such as [[dingbat]]s, to avoid privileging any particular allophone.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}}
==See also== *[[Allo-]] *[[Allophonic rule]] *[[Allomorph]] *[[Alternation (linguistics)]] *[[Diaphoneme]] *[[List of phonetics topics]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox language |name=Barranquenho |altname=Barranquian |states=[[Portugal]] |region=[[Barrancos]] |speakers=1,500 |date=no date |ref=<ref>{{e16|ext|Extremaduran (Portugal)}}</ref> |familycolor=Indo-European |fam2=[[Italic languages|Italic]] |fam3=[[Romance languages|Romance]] |fam4=[[Western Romance languages|Western]] |fam5=[[Ibero-Romance languages|Ibero-Romance]] |iso3=none |linglist=1oy |glotto=none }}
'''Barranquenho''' (''Barranquenhu''; [[English language|English]]: Barranquian<ref>[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_country.asp?name=PT Ethnologue report for Portugal]</ref>) is a [[Romance languages|Romance linguistic variety]] spoken in the [[Portugal|Portuguese]] town of [[Barrancos]], near the [[Spain|Spanish]] border. It is a [[mixed language]], and can be considered either a variety of [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] (Alentejan Portuguese) heavily influenced by the Spanish dialects of neighbouring areas in Spain in [[Extremadura]] and [[Andalusia]] (especially those from [[Encinasola]] and [[Rosal de la Frontera]]),<ref>[[Jos√© Leite de Vasconcelos]], ''Filologia Barranquenha - apontamentos para o seu estudo'', 1940.</ref> or a Spanish dialect (Extremaduran / Andalusian) heavily influenced by Portuguese.
Barranquian speakers say that they speak neither Spanish nor Portuguese but a third language altogether different. Although unlike some sources may state, Barranquenho is very easy to understand by speakers of both Portuguese and Spanish, as it is very close to both, and especially similar to the [[Andalusian Spanish|Andalusian]] dialect. [[Ethnologue]] lists Barranquian as a dialect of [[Extremaduran language|Extremaduran]], perhaps because Barrancos was populated by settlers from [[Badajoz]], a city in [[Extremadura]], though not in a [[Extremaduran language]] speaking area.<ref>Jos√© Ignacio Hualde, Antxon Olarrea, Erin O'Rourke (2012) ''The Handbook of Hispanic Linguistics'', p. 60</ref>
The development of Barranquenho seems to be relatively recent (in the past 200 years), unlike other minority linguistic varieties in the Iberian Peninsula which have medieval roots.
==Characteristics== The Portuguese base of this dialect is extremely hidden behind the Spanish dialects that mold it. The most characteristic aspect of this dialect is the aspiration of the 's' and 'z' in the end of the words, like in the Extremaduran and Andalusian dialects: 'cruh' (Portuguese/Spanish: cruz; English: cross), 'buhc√°' (Portuguese/Spanish: buscar; English: search) ... Sometimes the letters can be completely muted: 'uma b√™' (Portuguese: uma vez; English: once). The Portuguese 'j', 'ge' and 'gi' are pronounced like the Spanish [x].
The 'l' and 'r' in the end of the words are not pronounced: 'Manu√©' (Manuel), 'oliv√°' (olivar). But they appear again in the plural form: 'olivareh' (olivares). If the 'l' is at the end of a syllable it turns into 'r': 'argo' (algo). Like in Spanish, there is no differentiation between 'b' and 'v': vaca ['baka']. Just like in Extremaduran (or Brazilian Portuguese), the '-e' (English 'eh') in the end is pronounced like '-i' (English 'ee'): 'pobri' (pobre).
The Portuguese form of the first person of the plural 'n√≥s' is replaced by 'nusotrus' - a variation of the Spanish 'nosotros'. The placing of the pronouns is closer to the Spanish norm than to the Portuguese: 'se lav√¥' (Portuguese: lavou-se; Spanish: se lav√≥; English: has been washed).
It also contains many verbal forms of clearly Spanish conjugation: 'andubi' (Portuguese: andei, Spanish: anduve); 'supimos' (Portuguese: soubemos; Spanish: supimos).
==Recognition== The Portuguese government does not recognize nor protect the use of Barranquenho.
==See also== *[[Iberian languages]] *[[Languages of Portugal]] *[[Languages of Spain]] *[[Iberian Romance languages]] *[[Portunhol]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Languages of Portugal}} {{Portuguese dialects}}
[[Category:Languages of Portugal]] [[Category:Portuguese dialects]]

revision.text: [[File:Spam tutorial - local blacklisting.png|thumb|right|220px|Screenshot of a web page of a [[Wikimedia Foundation]]project. Filing a blacklisting request]] In [[computing]], a '''blacklist''' or '''block list''' is a basic [[access control]] mechanism that allows through all elements (email addresses, users, passwords, [[URLs]], [[IP address]]es, [[domain name]]s, file [[MD5 Hash|hashes]], etc.), except those explicitly mentioned. Those items on the list are denied access. The opposite is a [[whitelist]], which means only items on the list are let through whatever gate is being used. A [[Greylisting|greylist]] contains items that are temporarily blocked (or temporarily allowed) until an additional step is performed. Blacklists can be applied at various points in a security architecture, such as a [[Host (network)|host]], [[web proxy]], [[DNS]] servers, [[email]] server, [[Firewall (computing)|firewall]], [[directory server]]s or application authentication gateways. The type of element blocked is influenced by the access control location.{{Cite book|title = Introduction to Information Security: A Strategic-Based Approach|url = https://books√¨.google.com/books?id=eZBqAAAAQBAJ|publisher = Newnes|date = 2013-11-12|isbn = 9781597499729|language = en|first = Timothy|last = Shimeall|first2 = Jonathan|last2 = Spring}} DNS servers may be well-suited to block domain names, for example, but not URLs. A firewall is well-suited for blocking IP addresses, but less so for blocking malicious files or passwords. Example uses include a company that might prevent a list of software from running on its network, a school that might prevent access to a list of web sites from its computers, or a business that wants to ensure their computer users are not choosing easily guessed, poor passwords. ==Example systems to protect== Blacklists are used to protect a variety of systems in computing. The content of the blacklist is likely needs to be targeted to the type of system defended.{{Cite web|title = Domain Blacklist Ecosystem - A Case Study|url = https://insights.sei.cmu.edu/cert/2015/06/domain-blacklist-ecosystem---a-case-study.html|website = insights.sei.cmu.edu|access-date = 2016-02-04}} ===Information systems=== An information system includes end-point hosts like user machines and servers. A blacklist in this location may include certain types of software that are not allowed to run in the company environment. For example, a company might blacklist peer to peer file sharing on its systems. In addition to software, people, devices and Web sites can also be blacklisted.{{cite book|last=Rainer | first=Watson|title=Introduction to Information Systems|year=2012|publisher=Wiley Custom Learning Solutions|isbn=978-1-118-45213-4}} ===Email=== Most email providers have a [[Email spam|anti-spam]] feature that essentially blacklists certain [[email address]]es if they are deemed unwanted. How this happens is when a successful [[phishing]] attack (from an address that is forged from reliable accounts to try to recover personal information) is executed, then the email device deems the address to be spam, and proceeds to blacklist the address. An [[e-mail spam]] [[mail filter|filter]] may keep a blacklist of email addresses, any mail from which would be prevented from reaching its intended destination. It may also use sending domain names or sending IP addresses to implement a more general block. In addition to private email blacklists, there are lists that are kept for public use, examples are * China Anti-Spam Alliance http://anti-spam.org.cn/?locale=en_US * Fabel Spamsources https://mxtoolbox.com/problem/blacklist/fabelsources * [[Spam and Open Relay Blocking System]] * The DrMX Project ===Web browsing=== The goal of a blacklist in a web browser is to prevent the user from visiting a malicious or deceitful web page via filtering locally. A common web browsing blacklist is Google's [[Google Safe Browsing|Safe Browsing]], which is installed by default in Firefox, Safari, and Chrome. ===Usernames and passwords=== Blacklisting can also apply to user credentials. It is common for systems or websites to blacklist certain reserved usernames that are not allowed to be chosen by the system or website's user populations. These reserved usernames are commonly associated with built-in system administration functions. Password blacklists are very similar to username blacklists but typically contain significantly more entries than username blacklists. Password blacklists are applied to prevent users from choosing passwords that are easily guessed or are well known and could lead to unauthorized access by malicious parties. Password blacklists are deployed as an additional layer of security, usually in addition to a password policy, which sets the requirements of the password length and/or character complexity. This is because there are a significant number of password combinations that fulfill many password policies but are still easily guessed (i.e., Password123, Qwerty123). ==Distribution methods== Blacklists are distributed in a variety of ways. Some use simple [[mailing list]]s. A [[DNSBL]] is a common distribution method that leverages the [[Domain Name System|DNS]] itself. Some lists make use of [[rsync]] for high-volume exchanges of data.{{Cite web|title = Guidelines|url = http://www.surbl.org/guidelines|website = www.surbl.org|access-date = 2016-02-04}} Web-server functions may be used; either simple [[Hypertext Transfer Protocol|GET]] requests may be used or more complicated interfaces such as a [[RESTful API Modeling Language|RESTful]] API. ==Examples== * For a list of some DNS-based blacklists, see the [[Comparison of DNS blacklists]]. * Companies like [[Google]], [[Symantec]] and [[Sucuri]] keep internal blacklists of sites known to have malware and they display a warning before allowing the user to click them. * [[Content-control software]] such as [[DansGuardian]] and [[SquidGuard]] may work with a blacklist in order to block [[Uniform Resource Locator|URLs]] of sites deemed inappropriate for a work or educational environment. Such blacklists can be obtained free of charge or from commercial vendors such as [[Squidblacklist.org]]. * A [[Firewall (computing)|firewall]] or [[Intrusion detection system|IDS]] may also use a blacklist to block known hostile IP addresses and/or networks. An example for such a list would be the [[OpenBL]] project. * Many [[copy protection]] schemes include [[software blacklist]]ing. * The company [https://www.passwordrbl.com Password RBL] offers a password blacklist for Microsoft's [[Active Directory]], web sites and apps, distributed via a [[RESTful API Modeling Language|RESTful]] API. * Members of [[online auction]] sites may add other members to a personal blacklist. This means that they cannot bid on or ask questions about your auctions, nor can they use a "buy it now" function on your items. * Yet another form of list is the yellow list which is a list of email server IP addresses that send mostly good email but do send some spam. Examples include [[Yahoo]], [[Hotmail]], and [[Gmail]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} A yellow listed server is a server that should never be accidentally blacklisted. The yellow list is checked first and if listed then blacklist tests are ignored. * In [[Linux]] [[modprobe]], the blacklist modulename entry in a modprobe configuration file indicates that all of the particular [[loadable kernel module|module]]'s internal aliases are to be ignored. There are cases where two or more modules both support the same devices, or a module invalidly claims to support a device. * Many web browsers have the ability to consult anti-[[phishing]] blacklists in order to warn users who unwittingly aim to visit a [[Internet fraud|fraudulent website]]. * Many [[peer-to-peer file sharing]] programs support blacklists that block access from sites known to be owned by companies enforcing copyright. An example is the Bluetack{{cite web |url=http://www.bluetack.co.uk/forums/index.php?autocom=faq&CODE=02&qid=18 |title= B.I.S.S. Forums - FAQ - Questions about the Blocklists |work=Bluetack Internet Security Solutions |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081020052855/http://www.bluetack.co.uk/forums/index.php?autocom=faq&CODE=02&qid=18 |archivedate=2008-10-20 |accessdate=2015-08-01 }} blocklist set. ==Considerations of usage== As expressed in a recent conference paper focusing on blacklists of domain names and IP addresses used for Internet security, "these lists generally do not intersect. Therefore, it appears that these lists do not converge on one set of malicious indicators."{{Cite journal|title = Blacklist Ecosystem Analysis: Spanning Jan 2012 to Jun 2014|url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2808129|publisher = ACM|journal = Proceedings of the 2nd ACM Workshop on Information Sharing and Collaborative Security|date = 2015-01-01|pages = 13‚Äì22|first = Leigh|last = Metcalf|first2 = Jonathan M.|last2 = Spring}}{{Cite book|title = Paint It Black: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Malware Blacklists|url = https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-11379-1_1|publisher = Springer International Publishing|date = 2014-09-17|isbn = 9783319113784|pages = 1‚Äì21|series = Lecture Notes in Computer Science|doi = 10.1007/978-3-319-11379-1_1|language = en|first = Marc|last = K√ºhrer|first2 = Christian|last2 = Rossow|first3 = Thorsten|last3 = Holz|editor-first = Angelos|editor-last = Stavrou|editor-first2 = Herbert|editor-last2 = Bos|editor-first3 = Georgios|editor-last3 = Portokalidis}} This concern combined with an economic model{{Cite journal|title = Modeling malicious domain name take-down dynamics: Why eCrime pays|url = http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpls/abs_all.jsp?arnumber=6805779|publisher = IEEE|journal = eCrime Researchers Summit (eCRS), 2013|date = 2013-01-01|pages = 1‚Äì9|first = Jonathan M.|last = Spring}} means that, while blacklists are an essential part of network defense, they need to be used in concert with whitelists and greylists. An example would be the Adblock Plus blocklist that includes a number of features including whitelists within the blacklist by adding a prefix of two at symbols and two pipe symbols e.g. "@@||www.blocksite.com". ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.squidblacklist.org/ Squidblacklist.org - Blacklists For Squid Proxy and Content Filtering Applications.] * [https://www.ipfilterX.com/ ipfilterX by Nexus23 Labs - Blocks P2P Crawlers, Malware C&C IPs, Institutions and many more.] * [https://www.openbl.org/ OpenBL.org] - abuse reporting and blacklisting * [https://adblockplus.org/en/filters#whitelist / Adblock Plus Filter Features] - Adblock blacklist / whitelist features [[Category:Computer jargon]] [[Category:Computer security]] [[Category:Blacklisting|Computing]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Carolina Neurath | image = Carolina Neurath.jpg | caption = Neurath at a film premiere in Filmstaden in December 2012 | birthname = Anna Carolina Neurath | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1985|11|17|df=yes}} | birth_place = Segeltorp, Huddinge, Sweden | death_date = | death_place = | education = | occupation = Journalist, writer | title = | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = | alma_mater = [[Stockholm University]]
[[Poppius Journalistskola]] | religion = }} '''Anna Carolina Neurath''' (born 17 November 1985) is a Swedish journalist and writer. She specializes in writing business articles for the newspaper ''[[Svenska Dagbladet]]''. In 2016 her first work of fiction, ''Fartblinda'', was published. == Personal life == Neurath was born in 1985.{{cite web|url=http://www.norstedts.se/forfattare/Alfabetiskt/N/Carolina-Neurath/|title=Carolina Neurath|publisher=Norstedts.se|accessdate=21 December 2014|language=sv|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120315032237/http://www.norstedts.se/forfattare/Alfabetiskt/N/Carolina-Neurath/|archivedate=15 March 2012|df=dmy-all}}https://www.expressen.se/noje/svt-profilen-traffade-stora-karleken-nar-hon-var-sambo/ (Swedish) She studied journalism at the [[Stockholm University]] Department of Journalism, Media, and Communication (JMK) and then at [[Poppius Journalistskola]].{{cite web|url=http://www.poppius.se/index.phtml?id=569 |title=Frilanspristagare blir sommarpratare |publisher=Poppius.se |accessdate=22 December 2014 |language=sv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141223014142/http://www.poppius.se/index.phtml?id=569 |archivedate=23 December 2014 |df=dmy }}{{cite web|url=http://www.resume.se/nyheter/media/2011/08/20/caroline-neurath/ |title=Resum√©: "Hon kan g√• hur l√•ngt som helst" |accessdate=29 December 2014 |language=sv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229155923/http://www.resume.se/nyheter/media/2011/08/20/caroline-neurath/ |archivedate=29 December 2014 |df=dmy }}{{cite web|url=http://www.passionforbusiness.se/11407/ |title=Intervju med Carolina Neurath, andrapristagare "Sveriges br√•kigaste" 2014 |work=Passion for Business |accessdate=29 December 2014 |language=sv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141222005522/http://www.passionforbusiness.se/11407/ |archivedate=22 December 2014 |df=dmy }} She married in 2017 and has one child (born 2014).https://www.svenskdam.se/2017/08/se-bilderna-fran-kungavannens-magiska-brollop-i-skane/ (Swedish)http://inrikesmagasin.se/2014/05/27/carolina-neurath-brinner-granskande-naringslivsjournalistik/ (Swedish) == Career == Neurath began her career as a reporter for the business newspaper ''[[Dagens Industri]]''. She served as an editor on the Placera.nu website. In 2011, Neurath published ''Den stora bankh√§rvan: Finansparet Hagstr√∂mer och Qvibergs uppg√•ng och fall'', a book depicting the rise and fall of [[HQ Bank]] and the reasons for its failure.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UbQZtwAACAAJ&dq=carolina+neurath+finansparet&hl=sv&sa=X&ei=04OmVIqqNePOyQOMi4LoCw&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA|title=Den stora bankhrvan|accessdate=2 January 2015|language=sv}}{{cite web|url=http://www.resume.se/nyheter/media/2010/11/30/hq-kraschen-blir-bok|title=Resum√©: HQ-kraschen blir bok|publisher=Resume.se|date=30 November 2010|accessdate=21 December 2014|language=sv|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141221213104/http://www.resume.se/nyheter/media/2010/11/30/hq-kraschen-blir-bok/|archivedate=21 December 2014|df=dmy-all}}Aag√•rd, Martin (2 September 2011). [http://www.aftonbladet.se/kultur/article13567596.ab "Carolina Neurath: Den stora bankh√§rvan"] (in Swedish). ''[[Aftonbladet]] Kultur''. Retrieved 29 December 2014. On 19 July 2013, Neurath made a guest appearance as a "Sommarpratare" ("Summer Presenter") in the [[Sveriges Radio]] show ''[[Sommar (radio program)|Sommar i P1]]''.{{cite web|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/avsnitt/216115?programid=2071|title=Carolina Neurath|publisher=Sveriges Radio|date=19 July 2013|accessdate=21 December 2014|language=sv}} She also participated in [[SVT]]'s ''[[Sommarpratarna]]'' in October 2014.[http://www.svt.se/sommarpratarna/sommarpratarna-20-oktober-2014 ‚ÄùJag √∂verlevde men jag levde inte‚Äù | SVT.se] In 2014, Neurath released her second book, ''De svenska riskkapitalisterna'' (''The Swedish Venture Capitalists''), co-authored by Jan Almgren.{{cite web|url=http://www.norstedts.se/bocker/utgiven/2014/Host/neurath_carolina-de_svenska_riskkapitalisterna-inbunden|title=Neurath, C ‚Äì De svenska riskkapitalisterna ‚Äì 13055787|publisher=Norstedts.se|date=30 November 2010|accessdate=21 December 2014|language=sv}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gp.se/kulturnoje/recensioner/bocker/1.2494351-carolina-neurath-jan-almgren-de-svenska-riskkapitalisterna|title=Carolina Neurath Jan Almgren ‚Äì De svenska riskkapitalisterna|work=G√∂teborgs-Posten|date=19 September 2014|accessdate=21 December 2014|language=sv}}{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TiNVBAAAQBAJ&pg=PP1&dq=carolina+neurath&hl=sv&sa=X&ei=hYOmVJ6mA8m-ygOul4HACw&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=carolina%20neurath&f=false|title=De svenska riskkapitalisterna|accessdate=2 January 2015|language=sv}} The same year, Neurath's history of acting became news when the low budget [[fan film]] ''[[Star Wars: Threads of Destiny]]'' premiered, including 2006 footage of Neurath as Princess Arianna Ad'lah.{{cite web|url=http://www.svd.se/kultur/kultursvepet-20-2_3289452.svd?sidan=5|title=Kultursvepet 20/2|work=Svenska Dagbladet|date=20 February 2014|accessdate=22 December 2014|language=sv}} Her third book is her first work of fiction: a 2016 finance thriller called ''Fartblinda'' where a young female finance journalist attempts to uncover the business of shady financiers.[http://www.affarsvarlden.se/tidningen/article3955719.ece (in Swedish)] The rights for a TV series has been bought by FLX, a production company known for [[Felix Herngren]]s involvement.[http://www.resume.se/nyheter/artiklar/2016/02/23/carolina-neuraths-bok-blir-tv-serie--flx-producerar/ (in Swedish)] == Awards == Neurath has received various awards for her work. In 2010, she and a ''Svenska Dagbladet'' colleague, Jacob Bursell, were presented with the [[Guldspaden]] journalism award in the Larger Newspapers category for their coverage of the Swedish auditing industry.{{cite web|url=http://www.svd.se/naringsliv/negra-dn-spaden_6042355.svd |title=Gr√§vpris till SvD |work=Svenska Dagbladet |date=26 March 2011 |accessdate=21 December 2014 |language=sv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130722151808/http://www.svd.se/naringsliv/negra-dn-spaden_6042355.svd |archivedate=22 July 2013 }} [[File:Carolina Neurath 2013.jpg|thumb|left|150px|right|Carolina Neurath at the presentation of the hosts for [[Sommar i P1]] on 29 May 2013]] In 2011, Neurath was nominated for a second [[Guldspaden|Guldspaden award]] for her book ''Den stora bankh√§rvan: Finansparet Hagstr√∂mer och Qvibergs uppg√•ng och fall'', but did not win.{{cite web|url=http://www.svd.se/naringsliv/svd-trefaldigt-nominerad-till-guldspade_6894305.svd|title=SvD trefaldigt nominerad till guldspade|work=Svenska Dagbladet|date=2 March 2012|accessdate=21 December 2014|language=sv}}{{cite web|url=http://www.svd.se/nyheter/inrikes/storslam-i-guldspadar-for-svd_6950315.svd|title=Storslam i Guldspadar f√∂r SvD|work=Svenska Dagbladet|date=24 March 2012|accessdate=21 December 2014|language=sv}} The same year, Neurath was named one of "Sweden's Supertalents" by the newspaper ''[[Veckans Aff√§rer]]''; the ''[[Shortcut (magazine)|Shortcut]]'' magazine included her on its list, "√Örets uppstickare" ("Newcomer of the Year"). She was also named "Woman of the Year" by the newspaper ''[[Expressen]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.svd.se/naringsliv/arets-supertalang_6781083.svd|title=√Örets supertalang|author=Ylva Edenhall|work=Svenska Dagbladet|date=19 January 2012|accessdate=21 December 2014|language=sv}}{{cite web|url=http://shortcut.nu/artiklar/uppstickarna-2011-topplistan-1-30/|title=Uppstickarna 2011: Topplistan 1‚Äì30|work=Shortcut|accessdate=21 December 2014|language=sv}} In 2012, Neurath was awarded the [[Stora Journalistpriset]] for her work on the interest rate map.{{cite web|url=http://www.tv4play.se/program/malou-efter-tio?video_id=2244057|title=Carolina Neurath ber√§ttar om r√§ntekartan som kan s√§nka din bor√§nta|work=TV4 Play|accessdate=21 December 2014|language=sv}} She was also named Sweden's best business journalist by the public relations firm Halvarsson & Halvarsson in their yearly review of the financial market.{{cite web|url=http://www.halvarsson.se/Nyheter/2012/Carolina-Neurath-i-topp-bland-ekonomijournalister/ |title=Carolina Neurath i topp bland ekonomijournalister |publisher=Halvarsson.se |date=19 June 2012 |accessdate=21 December 2014 |language=sv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141221211759/http://www.halvarsson.se/Nyheter/2012/Carolina-Neurath-i-topp-bland-ekonomijournalister/ |archivedate=21 December 2014 |df=dmy }} In July 2013, Neurath was given the title "Powermama" of the year by the magazine ''[[Mama (magazine)|Mama]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.svd.se/naringsliv/carolina-neurath-utsedd-till-arets-powermama_4111873.svd|title=Carolina Neurath utsedd till √•rets powermama|work=Svenska Dagbladet|date=18 November 2014|accessdate=21 December 2014|language=sv}} Additionally, she was named one of the world's best investigative journalists by the international ''Monocle'' magazine.{{cite web|url=http://www.tv4.se/nyhetsmorgon/klipp/carolina-neurath-om-att-vara-en-av-v%C3%A4rldens-fr%C3%A4msta-gr%C3%A4vande-jorunalister-2970360|title=Carolina Neurath om att vara en av v√§rldens fr√§msta gr√§vande jorunalister ‚Äì Nyhetsmorgon|publisher=tv4.se|accessdate=21 December 2014|language=sv}} In 2014, Neurath was also awarded the [[Per Wendel-pris]] for her work in journalism, which came with a prize of 100,000 [[Swedish krona|SEK]].{{cite web|url=http://www.medievarlden.se/nyheter/2014/11/caroline-neruath-far-wendelpriset|title=Carolina Neurath f√•r Wendelpriset|publisher=Mediev√§rlden.se|accessdate=21 December 2014|language=sv}} == Works == *''Den stora bankh√§rvan: finansparet Hagstr√∂mer och Qvibergs uppg√•ng och fall'' Stockholm: Norstedt, 2011. Print. {{ISBN|9789113036984}} *''De svenska riskkapitalisterna: en ber√§ttelse om makt, pengar och hemligheter'' Stockholm: Norstedt, 2014. Print. {{ISBN|9789113055787}} *''Fartblinda'' Stockholm: Piratf√∂rlaget, 2016. Print. {{ISBN|9789164204752}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == *{{Commons category inline|Carolina Neurath}} *{{cite web |title=De svenska riskkapitalisterna" av Carolina Neurath och Jan Almgren |language=Swedish |date=6 August 2014 |publisher=[[YouTube]] |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KWHjlnMEy54 |accessdate=26 December 2014}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Neurath, Carolina}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1985 births]] [[Category:Swedish women writers]] [[Category:Swedish journalists]] [[Category:Stockholm University alumni]] [[Category:Swedish-language writers]] [[Category:Writers from Stockholm]] [[Category:Women journalists]] [[Category:21st-century Swedish writers]] [[Category:21st-century women writers]] [[Category:Swedish women journalists]] [[Category:21st-century Swedish journalists]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox writing system |name=Cherokee |type=[[Syllabary]] |time=1820s<ref name="Owyeah">[[Cherokee syllabary#CITEREFSturtevantFogelson2004|Sturtevant & Fogelson 2004]], p. 337.</ref>‚Äìpresent<ref name = britannica>{{cite web|url= http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/109503/Cherokee-language|title=Cherokee language|website= www.britannica.com|publisher=Encyclop√¶dia Britannica |accessdate=22 May 2014}}</ref> |languages=[[Cherokee language]] |fam1= [[Egyptian hieroglyphs]] |fam2=[[Proto-Sinaitic]] |fam3=[[Phoenician alphabet]] |fam4=[[Greek alphabet]] |fam5=[[Latin script]] and [[Cyrillic script]] |unicode = {{ublist |class=nowrap |[https://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/U13A0.pdf U+13A0‚ÄìU+13FF] {{smaller|Cherokee}} |[https://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/UAB70.pdf U+AB70‚ÄìU+ABBF] {{smaller|Cherokee Supplement}}}} |iso15924=Cher}} {{Cherokee language|state=expanded}} {{Contains Cherokee text}} {{alphabet}} The '''Cherokee syllabary''' is a [[syllabary]] invented by [[Sequoyah]] to write the [[Cherokee language]] in the late 1810s and early 1820s. His creation of the syllabary is particularly noteworthy as he could not previously read any script.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Diamond|first1=Jared|title=Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies|date=1999|publisher=Norton|location=New York, New York|isbn=0393317552|page=228}}</ref> He first experimented with [[logogram]]s, but his system later developed into a syllabary. In his system, each symbol represents a [[syllable]] rather than a single [[phoneme]]; the 85 (originally 86){{sfn|Sturtevant|Fogelson|2004|p=337}} characters provide a suitable method to write Cherokee. Although some symbols resemble [[Latin alphabet|Latin]], [[Greek alphabet|Greek]], and [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]] letters, the relationship between symbols and sounds is different.
==Description== [[File:Sequoyah.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[Sequoyah]], inventor of the Cherokee syllabary]] Each of the characters represents one syllable, as in the [[Japanese language|Japanese]] ''[[kana]]'' and the [[Bronze Age]] Greek [[Linear B]] writing systems. The first six characters represent isolated [[Cardinal vowel|vowel]] syllables. Characters for combined consonant and vowel syllables then follow.
The charts below show the syllabary in recitation order, left to right, top to bottom as arranged by [[Samuel Worcester]], along with his commonly used transliterations.{{Sfn | Walker | Sarbaugh | 1993 | p = 72, 76}}{{Sfn | Giasson | 2004 | p = 42}} He played a key role in the development of [[Cherokee printing]] from 1828 until his death in 1859.
{| class="wikitable nounderlines" | colspan="20" style="font-size: smaller" | ''The chart below uses [[Unicode]] characters from the [[Cherokee (Unicode block)|Cherokee]] block.'' The Latin letter 'v' in the transcriptions, seen in the last column, represents a [[nasal vowel]], /…ôÃÉ/.
The Cherokee character ·èô ''do'' has a different orientation in old documents, resembling a Greek Œõ (or barless A) rather than a Latin V as in modern documents.{{refn|group=note|name=old-do| There is a difference between the old form of ''do'' (Œõ-like) and the modern form of ''do'' (V-like). The standard Digohweli font displays the modern form. Old Do Digohweli and Code2000 fonts both display the old form.<ref>{{Citation | url = http://www.languagegeek.com/font/fontdownload.html#Cherokee | title = Language geek font download | contribution = Cherokee}}</ref>}}
Note that the 86th character (·èµ, ''mv'') is obsolete.{{refn|group=note|name=mv|Most sources, including materials produced by the Cherokee Nation, state that this character represented the ''mv'' syllable.<ref name="SyllabaryChart">{{cite web|title=Syllabary Chart|url=http://cherokee.org/Portals/0/Documents/Language/syllabary%20chart.pdf?ver=2017-08-04-145035-983|publisher=Cherokee Nation|accessdate=15 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="Cushman2013p93">Cushman 2013, p. 93.</ref><ref name="unicode9">{{cite web|title=Cherokee: Range: 13A0‚Äì13FF|url=https://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/U13A0.pdf|website=The Unicode Standard, Version 9.0|accessdate=10 June 2017}}</ref> However, Worcester wrote that it represented a syllable similar to ''hv'', but more open.{{Sfn | Walker | Sarbaugh | 1993 | p = 77, 89‚Äì90}}}} There is also a handwritten cursive form of the syllabary;<ref>http://www.omniglot.com/images/writing/cherokee_orig.gif</ref> notably, the handwritten glyphs bear little resemblance to the printed forms.
=== Detailed considerations === The phonetic values of these characters do not equate directly to those represented by the letters of the Latin script. Some characters represent two distinct phonetic values (actually heard as different syllables), while others may represent multiple variations of the same syllable.{{Sfn | Walker | Sarbaugh | 1993 | p = 72‚Äì75}} Not all [[phoneme|phonemic]] distinctions of the spoken language are represented. For example, while /d/ + vowel syllables are mostly differentiated from /t/+vowel by use of different graphs, syllables beginning with /g/ are all conflated with those beginning with /k/, so that in most cases, /k/ is written with a glyph in the ''g'' row. Also, long vowels are not ordinarily distinguished from short vowels, tones are not marked, and there is no regular rule for representing consonant clusters. However, in more recent technical literature, length of vowels can actually be indicated using a colon.
Six distinctive vowel qualities are represented in the Cherokee syllabary based on where they are pronounced in the mouth, including the high vowels ''i'' and ''u'', mid vowels ''e, v'', and ''o'', and low vowel ''a''. The syllabary also does not distinguish among syllables that end in vowels, ''h,'' or glottal stop. For example, the single symbol, ·èë, is used to represent ''su'' in ''su:dali'', meaning ''six'' (·èë·èì·éµ). This same symbol ·èë represents ''suh'' as in ''suhdi,'' meaning 'fishhook' (·èë·èó). Therefore, there is no differentiation among the symbols used for syllables ending in a single vowel versus that vowel plus "h."
When consonants other than ''s, h,'' or glottal stop arise with other consonants in clusters, the appropriate consonant plus a "dummy vowel" is used. This dummy vowel is not pronounced and is either chosen arbitrarily or for etymological reasons (reflecting an underlying etymological vowel). For example, ·èß·éæ·èç·èó (tsu-na-s-di) represents the word ''ju:nsdi'', meaning 'small.' ''Ns'' in this case is the consonant cluster that requires the following dummy vowel, ''a''. ''Ns'' is written as ·éæ·èç /nas/. The vowel is included in the transliteration, but is not pronounced in the word (''ju:nsdi''). (The transliterated ''ts'' represents the affricate ''j'').{{Sfn | Scancarelli | 2005}}{{Rp | needed = yes|date=December 2012}} Adult speakers can distinguish words by context.
If a labial consonant such as ''p'' or ''b'' appears in a borrowed word or name, it is written using the ''qu'' row. This /kw/ ~ /p/ correspondence is a known linguistic phenomenon that exists elsewhere (cf. [[P-Celtic]], [[Osco-Umbrian]], [[Telerin]]).
=== Transliteration issues === Some Cherokee words pose a problem for transliteration software because they contain adjacent pairs of single letter symbols that (without special provisions) would be combined when doing the back conversion from Latin script to Cherokee. Here are a few examples: * ·é¢·è£·éµ·èç·é†·èÅ·èó = ''itsalisanedi'' = ''i-tsa-li-s-a-ne-di'' * ·é§·éµ·é©·è≥·èç·é†·èÖ·èÅ = ''uligiyusanvne'' = ''u-li-gi-yu-s-a-nv-ne'' * ·é§·èÇ·è∞·èç·é¢·è± = ''uniyesiyi'' = ''u-ni-ye-s-i-yi'' * ·éæ·èç·é¢·èØ = ''nasiya'' = ''na-s-i-ya'' For these examples, the back conversion is likely to join ''s-a'' as ''sa'' or ''s-i'' as ''si''. One solution is to use an apostrophe to separate the two,{{citation needed|date=October 2017}} as is done in Japanese (e.g.: [[Man'yogana]]): ''itsalis'anedi''.
Other Cherokee words contain character pairs that entail overlapping transliteration sequences. Examples: * ·èÄ·éæ transliterates as ''nahna'', yet so does ·éæ·éø. The former is ''nah-na'', the latter is ''na-hna''. If the Latin script is parsed from left to right, longest match first, then without special provisions, the back conversion would be wrong for the latter. There are several similar examples involving these character combinations: ''naha nahe nahi naho nahu nahv''.
A further problem encountered in transliterating Cherokee is that there are some pairs of different Cherokee words that transliterate to the same word in the Latin script. Here are some examples: * ·é†·èç·é°·èÉ and ·é†·èé·èÉ both transliterate to ''aseno'' * ·é®·èç·é•·é¢ and ·é®·èí·é¢ both transliterate to ''gesvi'' Without special provision, a round trip conversion may change ·é†·èç·é°·èÉ to ·é†·èé·èÉ and change ·é®·èç·é•·é¢ to ·é®·èí·é¢.
==Character orders== [[File:Cherokee syllabary original order.png|thumb|Original Cherokee syllabary order, with the now obsolete letter ·èµ in red]] # The usual alphabetical order for Cherokee runs across the rows of the syllabary chart from left to right, top to bottom‚Äîthis is the one used in the Unicode block: ·é† (a), ·é° (e), ·é¢ (i), ·é£ (o), ·é§ (u), ·é• (v), ·é¶ (ga), ·éß (ka), ·é® (ge), ·é© (gi), ·é™ (go), ·é´ (gu), ·é¨ (gv), ·é≠ (ha), ·éÆ (he), ·éØ (hi), ·é∞ (ho), ·é± (hu), ·é≤ (hv), ·é≥ (la), ·é¥ (le), ·éµ (li), ·é∂ (lo), ·é∑ (lu), ·é∏ (lv), ·éπ (ma), ·é∫ (me), ·éª (mi), ·éº (mo), ·éΩ (mu), ·éæ (na), ·éø (hna), ·èÄ (nah), ·èÅ (ne), ·èÇ (ni), ·èÉ (no), ·èÑ (nu), ·èÖ (nv), ·èÜ (qua), ·èá (que), ·èà (qui), ·èâ (quo), ·èä (quu), ·èã (quv), ·èå (sa), ·èç (s), ·èé (se), ·èè (si), ·èê (so), ·èë (su), ·èí (sv), ·èì (da), ·èî (ta), ·èï (de), ·èñ (te), ·èó (di), ·èò (ti), ·èô (do), ·èö (du), ·èõ (dv), ·èú (dla), ·èù (tla), ·èû (tle), ·èü (tli), ·è† (tlo), ·è° (tlu), ·è¢ (tlv), ·è£ (tsa), ·è§ (tse), ·è• (tsi), ·è¶ (tso), ·èß (tsu), ·è® (tsv), ·è© (wa), ·è™ (we), ·è´ (wi), ·è¨ (wo), ·è≠ (wu), ·èÆ (wv), ·èØ (ya), ·è∞ (ye), ·è± (yi), ·è≤ (yo), ·è≥ (yu), ·è¥ (yv). # Cherokee has also been alphabetized based on the six columns of the syllabary chart from top to bottom, left to right: ·é† (a), ·é¶ (ga), ·éß (ka), ·é≠ (ha), ·é≥ (la), ·éπ (ma), ·éæ (na), ·éø (hna), ·èÄ (nah), ·èÜ (qua), ·èç (s), ·èå (sa), ·èì (da), ·èî (ta), ·èú (dla), ·èù (tla), ·è£ (tsa), ·è© (wa), ·èØ (ya), ·é° (e), ·é® (ge), ·éÆ (he), ·é¥ (le), ·é∫ (me), ·èÅ (ne), ·èá (que), ·èé (se), ·èï (de), ·èñ (te), ·èû (tle), ·è§ (tse), ·è™ (we), ·è∞ (ye), ·é¢ (i), ·é© (gi), ·éØ (hi), ·éµ (li), ·éª (mi), ·èÇ (ni), ·èà (qui), ·èè (si), ·èó (di), ·èò (ti), ·èü (tli), ·è• (tsi), ·è´ (wi), ·è± (yi), ·é£ (o), ·é™ (go), ·é∞ (ho), ·é∂ (lo), ·éº (mo), ·èÉ (no), ·èâ (quo), ·èê (so), ·èô (do), ·è† (tlo), ·è¶ (tso), ·è¨ (wo), ·è≤ (yo), ·é§ (u), ·é´ (gu), ·é± (hu), ·é∑ (lu), ·éΩ (mu), ·èÑ (nu), ·èä (quu), ·èë (su), ·èö (du), ·è° (tlu), ·èß (tsu), ·è≠ (wu), ·è≥ (yu), ·é• (v), ·é¨ (gv), ·é≤ (hv), ·é∏ (lv), ·èÖ (nv), ·èã (quv), ·èí (sv), ·èõ (dv), ·è¢ (tlv), ·è® (tsv), ·èÆ (wv), ·è¥ (yv). # Sequoyah used a completely different alphabetical order: ·é° (e), ·é† (a), ·é≥ (la), ·è• (tsi), ·èÄ (nah), ·è≠ (wu), ·è™ (we), ·éµ (li), ·èÅ (ne), ·éº (mo), ·é© (gi), ·è± (yi), ·èè (si), ·è¢ (tlv), ·é£ (o), ·é∑ (lu), ·é¥ (le), ·é≠ (ha), ·è¨ (wo), ·è† (tlo), ·èî (ta), ·è¥ (yv), ·é∏ (lv), ·éØ (hi), ·èç (s), ·è≤ (yo), ·é± (hu), ·é™ (go), ·èß (tsu), ·éΩ (mu), ·èé (se), ·èê (so), ·èü (tli), ·èà (qui), ·èá (que), ·èå (sa), ·èÜ (qua), ·èÉ (no), ·éß (ka), ·è® (tsv), ·èí (sv), ·èÇ (ni), ·é¶ (ga), ·èô (do), ·é® (ge), ·èì (da), ·é¨ (gv), ·è´ (wi), ·é¢ (i), ·é§ (u), ·è∞ (ye), ·é≤ (hv), ·èõ (dv), ·é´ (gu), ·è¶ (tso), ·èâ (quo), ·èÑ (nu), ·éæ (na), ·é∂ (lo), ·è≥ (yu), ·è§ (tse), ·èó (di), ·èÆ (wv), ·èö(du), ·èï (de), ·è£ (tsa), ·é• (v), ·èÖ (nv), ·èñ (te), ·éπ (ma), ·èë (su), ·è° (tlu), ·éÆ (he), ·é∞ (ho), ·éª (mi), ·èù (tla), ·èØ (ya), ·è© (wa), ·èò (ti), ·èû (tle), ·éø (hna), ·èä (quu), ·èú (dla), ·é∫ (me), ·èã (quv).
==Numerals== Cherokee uses [[Arabic numerals]] (0‚Äì9). Sequoyah proposed a system of numerals for Cherokee, but his system was never adopted.{{Sfn | Giasson | 2004 | p = 7}} Sequoyah's system included symbols for 1‚Äì20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90, 100 as well as a symbol for three zeros for numbers in the thousands and a symbol for six zeros for numbers in the millions. These last two symbols representing 000 and 000,000 are made up of three separate symbols each.
==Early history== {{main|Sequoyah}} [[File:Original Cherokee Syllabary.jpg|thumb|Sequoyah's original syllabary characters, showing both the script forms and the print forms]] {{external media | width = 210px | float = right | | video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r3QKRzq5M5Y The Cherokee Syllabary], NCLLP<ref name="ncllp">{{cite web | title =The North Carolina Language and Life Project | work = | publisher = | date = | url =https://ncsu.edu/linguistics/ncllp/index.php | accessdate =April 2, 2016 }}</ref> }} Around 1809, impressed by the "talking leaves" of European written languages, Sequoyah began work to create a writing system for the Cherokee language. After attempting to create a character for each word, Sequoyah realized this would be too difficult and eventually created characters to represent syllables. Sequoyah took some ideas from his copy of the Bible, which he studied for characters to use in print, noticing the simplicity of the Roman letters and adopting them to make the writing of his syllabary easier. He worked on the syllabary for twelve years before completion, and dropped or modified most of the characters he originally created.
After the syllabary was completed in the early 1820s, it achieved almost instantaneous popularity and spread rapidly throughout Cherokee society.{{Sfn | Walker | Sarbaugh | 1993 | p = 70‚Äì72}} By 1825, the majority of Cherokees could read and write in their newly developed orthography.{{Sfn | McLaughlin | 1986 | p = 353}}
Some of Sequoyah's most learned contemporaries immediately understood that the syllabary was a great invention. For example, when [[Albert Gallatin]], a politician and trained linguist, saw a copy of Sequoyah's syllabary, he believed it was superior to the English alphabet. He recognized that even though the Cherokee student must learn 85 characters instead of 26 for English, the Cherokee could read immediately after learning all the symbols. The Cherokee student could accomplish in a few weeks what students of English writing might require two years to achieve.<ref>Langguth, A. J. (2010). ''Driven West: Andrew Jackson and the Trail of Tears to the Civil War''. New York, Simon & Schuster. p. 71. {{ISBN|978-1-4165-4859-1}}.</ref>
In 1828, the order of the characters in a chart and the shapes of the characters were modified by Cherokee author and editor [[Elias Boudinot (Cherokee)|Elias Boudinot]] to adapt the syllabary to printing presses.<ref name = ict>[http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2010/03/16/cherokee-nation-creates-syllabary-keypad-81743 "Cherokee Nation creates syllabary keypad."] ''Indian Country Today.'' 17 March 2010 (retrieved 1 October 2016)</ref> The 86th character was dropped entirely.{{Sfn | Kilpatrick | Kilpatrick | 1968 | p = 23}} Following these changes, the syllabary was adopted by the ''[[Cherokee Phoenix]]'' newspaper, later ''[[Cherokee Advocate]]'', followed by the ''Cherokee Messenger'', a bilingual paper printed in [[Indian Territory]] in the mid-19th century.{{Sfn | Sturtevant | Fogelson | 2004 | p = 362}}
In 1834, Worcester made changes to several characters in order to improve the readability of Cherokee text. Most notably, he inverted the ''do'' character (·èô) so that it could not be confused with the ''go'' character (·é™).{{Sfn | Giasson | 2004 | p = 29‚Äì33}} Otherwise, the characters remained remarkably invariant until the advent of new typesetting technologies in the 20th century.{{Sfn | Giasson | 2004 | p = 35}}
==Later developments== [[File:Cherokee Central Schools.jpg|thumb|Sign in [[Cherokee, North Carolina]]]] [[File:Cherokee stop sign.png|thumb|right|175px|Cherokee syllabary in use today, [[Tahlequah, Oklahoma]]]] In the 1960s, the Cherokee Phoenix Press began publishing literature in the Cherokee syllabary, including the ''Cherokee Singing Book''.{{Sfn | Sturtevant | Fogelson | 2004 | p = 750}} A Cherokee syllabary typewriter ball was developed for the [[IBM Selectric]] in the late 1970s. Computer fonts greatly expanded Cherokee writers' ability to publish in Cherokee. In 2010, a Cherokee keyboard cover was developed by [[Roy Boney, Jr.]] and [[Joseph Erb]], facilitating more rapid typing in Cherokee. The keyboard cover is now used by students in the [[Cherokee Nation]] Immersion School, where all coursework is written in syllabary.<ref name = ict/>
In August 2010, the [[Oconaluftee Institute for Cultural Arts]] in [[Cherokee, North Carolina]] acquired a letterpress and had the Cherokee syllabary recast to begin printing one-of-a-kind fine art books and prints in syllabary.<ref name="SCC">[http://www.southwesterncc.edu/news/10-jul-sept/letterpress.htm "Letterpress arrives at OICA"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101130021125/http://www.southwesterncc.edu/news/10-jul-sept/letterpress.htm |date=November 30, 2010 }} ''Southwestern Community College'' (retrieved 21 Nov 2010)</ref> Artists Jeff Marley and [[Frank Brannon]] completed a collaborative project on October 19, 2013, in which they printed using Cherokee syllabary type from [[Southwestern Community College (North Carolina)|Southwestern Community College]] in the print shop at [[New Echota]]. This was the first time syllabary type has been used at New Echota since 1835.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.northwestgeorgianews.com/calhoun_times/news/local/new-echota-days-begin-this-saturday/article_5da73114-37fd-11e3-91e7-0019bb30f31a.html|title=New Echota days begin this Saturday|publisher=Calhoun Times|date=Oct 18, 2013|accessdate=21 July 2017|subscription=yes}}</ref>
In 2015 the Unicode Consortium encoded a lowercase version of the script, since typists would often set Cherokee with two different point sizes, so as to mark beginnings of sentences and given names (as in the Latin alphabet). Handwritten Cherokee also shows a difference in lower- and uppercase letters, such as descenders and ascenders.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.unicode.org/L2/L2014/14064-n4537-cherokee.pdf |format=PDF |title=Working group Document : Revised proposal for the addition of Cherokee characters to the UCS |publisher=Unicode.org |accessdate=2015-06-21}}</ref> Lowercase Cherokee has already been encoded in the font [[Everson Mono]].
The syllabary is finding increasingly diverse usage today, from books, newspapers, and websites to the street signs of [[Tahlequah, Oklahoma]] and [[Cherokee, North Carolina]]. An increasing corpus of children's literature is printed in Cherokee syllabary to meet the needs of Cherokee students in the Cherokee language immersion schools in Oklahoma and North Carolina.{{citation needed| date= June 2017}}
==Possible influence on Liberian Vai syllabary== In recent years evidence has emerged suggesting that the Cherokee syllabary provided a model for the design of the [[Vai script|Vai syllabary]] in [[Liberia]], Africa. The Vai syllabary emerged about 1832/33. The link appears to have been Cherokee who emigrated to Liberia after the invention of the Cherokee syllabary (which in its early years spread rapidly among the Cherokee) but before the invention of the Vai syllabary. One such man, Austin Curtis, married into a prominent [[Vai people|Vai]] family and became an important Vai chief himself. It is perhaps not coincidence that the "inscription on a house" that drew the world's attention to the existence of the Vai script was in fact on the home of Curtis, a Cherokee.{{Sfn | Tuchscherer | 2002}} There also appears to be a connection between an early form of written [[Bassa language|Bassa]] and the earlier Cherokee syllabary.
==Classes== [[File:Cherokeeclass.png|thumb|right|Oklahoma [[Cherokee language]] immersion school student writing in the Cherokee syllabary.]] Cherokee languages classes typically begin with a transliteration of Cherokee into Roman letters, only later incorporating the syllabary. The Cherokee language classes offered through [[Haskell Indian Nations University]], [[Northeastern State University]],<ref name=ict/> the [[University of Oklahoma]], the [[University of Science and Arts of Oklahoma]], [[Western Carolina University]], and the elementary school immersion classes offered by the Cherokee Nation and the [[Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians]] Immersion School<ref>[http://www.wcu.edu/6314.asp "Cherokee Language Revitalization Project."] ''Western Carolina University.'' (retrieved 23 Aug 2010)</ref> all teach the syllabary. The fine arts degree program at [[Southwestern Community College (North Carolina)|Southwestern Community College]] incorporates the syllabary in its printmaking classes.<ref name="SCC" />
==Unicode== Cherokee was added to the [[Unicode]] Standard in September, 1999 with the release of version 3.0. On June 17, 2015, with the release of version 8.0, Cherokee was redefined as a [[bicameral script]]; the character repertoire was extended to include a complete set of lowercase Cherokee letters as well as the archaic character (·èµ).
===Blocks=== {{Main|Cherokee (Unicode block)|Cherokee Supplement|l2=Cherokee Supplement (Unicode block)}}
The first Unicode block for Cherokee is U+13A0–U+13FF. It contains all 86 uppercase letters, together with six lowercase letters:{{refn|group=note|The PDF Unicode chart shows the modern form of the letter ''do''.}} {{Unicode chart Cherokee}}
The Cherokee Supplement block is U+AB70–U+ABBF. It contains the remaining 80 lowercase letters. {{Unicode chart Cherokee Supplement}}
===Fonts=== A single Cherokee Unicode font, Plantagenet Cherokee, is supplied with [[macOS]], version 10.3 (Panther) and later. [[Windows Vista]] also includes a Cherokee font. Several free Cherokee fonts are available including Digohweli, Donisiladv, and [[Noto fonts|Noto Sans Cherokee]]. Some pan-Unicode fonts, such as [[Code2000]], [[Everson Mono]], and [[GNU FreeFont]], include Cherokee characters. A commercial font, Phoreus Cherokee, published by TypeCulture, includes multiple weights and styles.<ref>{{cite web|title=Phoreus Cherokee|url=http://typeculture.com/foundry/font-collection/phoreus-cherokee/|website=TypeCulture|accessdate=15 January 2018}}</ref>

author1-link = Konrad Tuchscherer| last1 = Tuchscherer | first1 = Konrad | year = 2002 | first2 = PEH | last2 = Hair | title = Cherokee and West Africa: Examining the Origins of the Vai Script | journal = History in Africa | volume = 29 | pages = 427‚Äì86 | doi=10.2307/3172173}}. * {{Citation | editor1-last = Sturtevant | editor1-first = William C. | editor2-first = Raymond D. | editor2-last = Fogelson | title = Handbook of North American Indians: Southeast | volume = 14 | place = Washington, DC | publisher = Smithsonian Institution | year = 2004 | ISBN = 0160723000}}. * {{Citation | last1 = Walker | first1 = Willard | first2 = James | last2 = Sarbaugh | year = 1993 | title = The Early History of the Cherokee Syllabary | journal = Ethnohistory | volume = 40 | number = 1 | pages = 70‚Äì94 | doi=10.2307/482159}}.

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=March 2018}} In sports, a '''depth chart''' is used to show the placements of the starting players and the secondary players. Generally a starting player will be listed first or on top while a back-up will be listed below. Depth charts also tend to resemble the actual position locations of certain players.<ref name="LongCzarnecki2011">{{cite book|author1=Howie Long|author2=John Czarnecki|title=Football For Dummies, USA Edition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=an8ZIHOMda0C&pg=PA244|accessdate=31 July 2013|date=12 May 2011|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-118-01265-9|pages=244‚Äì|quote=A depth chart lists the starting lineups for both teams by their positions on offense and defense.}}</ref>
The typical [[Major League Baseball]] depth chart consists of a list of players at each position, with the starter or first-string player listed first, followed by replacement and [[Platoon system|platoon players]]. For [[fantasy baseball]], typical preseason projection systems such as [[PECOTA]] construct depth charts that specify not just the order of the players at each position (starter, replacement or [[List of baseball jargon (B)#bench|bench player]]) but also the amount of playing time each person at that position will have. For example, at first base one player may be projected as playing 60 percent of the innings, and another 40 percent for the coming season, while at catcher one player may be projected as playing 80 percent of the innings, and another 20 percent. For pitchers, the depth charts project the number of innings each roster player will pitch.
The [[line (ice hockey)|line system]] in [[ice hockey]] follows the same structure as a depth chart.
==Outside of sports== The term depth chart is now also being used from the perspective of management theory, to address the process of key positioning leaders within the organization, considering a dynamic [[Product lifecycle (engineering)|life cycle]] perspective which includes developmental tasks such as those cited in books and articles related to the leadership pipeline subject. A depth chart analysis for key positioning leaders should affect the development of leadership training programs and high performance development initiatives in modern corporations and enterprises.
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Diagrams]] [[Category:Sports terminology]]

revision.text:
{{See also|Interpretation (logic)}}
According to [[Rudolf Carnap]], in [[logic]], an interpretation is a '''descriptive interpretation''' (also called a '''factual interpretation''') if at least one of the undefined symbols of its [[formal system]] becomes, in the interpretation, a ''[[descriptive sign]]'' (i.e., the name of single objects, or observable properties).<ref name="itslaia">[[Rudolf Carnap|Carnap, Rudolf]], ''Introduction to Symbolic Logic and its Applications''</ref> In his ''Introduction to Semantics'' (Harvard Uni. Press, 1942) he makes a distinction between formal interpretations which are ''[[logical interpretation]]s'' (also called ''mathematical interpretation'' or ''logico-mathematical interpretation'') and ''descriptive interpretations'': a formal interpretation is a ''descriptive interpretation'' if it is not a ''logical interpretation''.<ref name="itslaia"/>
Attempts to [[Axiomatic system|axiomatize]] the [[empirical science]]s, Carnap said, use a ''descriptive interpretation'' to model reality.:<ref name="itslaia"/> the aim of these attempts is to construct a [[formal system]] for which [[reality]] is the only interpretation.<ref name="tcarotmim">The Concept and the Role of the Model in Mathematics and Natural and Social Sciences</ref> - the world is an interpretation (or model) of these sciences, only insofar as these sciences are true.<ref name="tcarotmim"/>
Any non-empty set may be chosen as the domain of a descriptive interpretation, and all n-ary relations among the elements of the domain are candidates for assignment to any predicate of degree n.<ref>{{cite book | last = Mates | first = Benson | title = Elementary Logic, Second Edition | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] | year = 1972 | location = New York | pages = 56 | isbn = 0-19-501491-X }}</ref>
==Examples==
A sentence is either ''true'' or ''false'' under an ''interpretation'' which assigns values to the logical variables. We might for example make the following assignments:
'''Individual constants''' * a: Socrates * b: Plato * c: Aristotle '''Predicates''': * FŒ±: Œ± is sleeping * GŒ±Œ≤: Œ± hates Œ≤ * HŒ±Œ≤Œ≥: Œ± made Œ≤ hit Œ≥
'''Sentential variables:''' * ''p'' "It is raining."
Under this interpretation the sentences discussed above would represent the following English statements: * ''p'': "It is raining." * ''F''(''a''): "Socrates is sleeping." * ''H''(''b'',''a'',''c''): "Plato made Socrates hit Aristotle." * {{all}}''x''(''F''(''x'')): "Everybody is sleeping." * {{exist}}''z''(''G''(''a'',''z'')): "Socrates hates somebody." * {{exist}}''x''{{all}}''y''{{exist}}''z''(''H''(''x'',''y'',''z'')): "Somebody made everybody hit somebody." * {{all}}''x''{{exist}}''z''(''F''(''x''){{and}}''G''(''a'',''z'')): Everybody is sleeping and Socrates hates somebody. * {{exist}}''x''{{all}}''y''{{exist}}''z'' (''G''(''a'',''z''){{or-}}''H''(''x'',''y'',''z'')): Either Socrates hates somebody or somebody made everybody hit somebody.
== Sources == {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Descriptive Interpretation}} [[Category:Semantics]] [[Category:Formal languages]] [[Category:Interpretation (philosophy)]]

revision.text:
{{grammar|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox writer | name = Dhansukhlal Mehta | image = DhansukhlalMehtaPic.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Dhansukhlal Krishnalal Mehta | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=y|1890|10|20}} | birth_place = [[Wadhwan]], [[Gujarat]], India | death_date = {{Death date and age|1974|8|29|1890|10|20}} | death_place = | occupation = Novelist, short story writer, humourist | language = [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]] | residence = | nationality = [[India]]n | education = | alma_mater = [[Veermata Jijabai Technological Institute]] | period = | genre = Short story, novel | movement = | notableworks = ''[[Ame Badha]]'' (1935) | spouse = | children = | awards = {{plainlist| * [[Ranjitram Suvarna Chandrak]] (1940) * [[Narmad Suvarna Chandrak]] (1957) }} | signature = Dhansukhlal Mehta autograph.svg }}
'''Dhansukhlal Krishnalal Mehta''' was a [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]] writer from [[Gujarat]], India. He is considered a pioneer of Gujarati short stories. His humorous novel ''[[Ame Badha]]'', co-written with [[Jyotindra Dave]], is widely regarded as one of the best humorous novels in [[Gujarati literature]]. He received the [[Ranjitram Suvarna Chandrak]] in 1940 and the [[Narmad Suvarna Chandrak]] in 1957.
==Life== Dhansukhlal Mehta was born on October 20th, 1890 in the city of [[Wadhwan]], which is on the [[Kathiawar]] peninsula (now in [[Surendranagar district]], Gujarat). His family was native to [[Surat]]. After completing his schooling in Wadhwan, [[Palitana]] and Surat, he obtained a diploma from [[Victoria Jubilee Technical Institute]], [[Mumbai]]. From 1914 to 1925, he worked at various places in Mumbai, before joining [[Scindia Steam Navigation Company Ltd.]] in 1925. .<ref name="Gujarati Sahitya Parishad">{{cite web | title=‡™∏‡™µ‡™ø‡™∂‡´á‡™∑ ‡™™‡™∞‡™ø‡™ö‡™Ø: ‡™ß‡™®‡™∏‡´Å‡™ñ‡™≤‡™æ‡™≤ ‡™Æ‡™π‡´á‡™§‡™æ, ‡™ó‡´Å‡™ú‡™∞‡™æ‡™§‡´Ä ‡™∏‡™æ‡™π‡™ø‡™§‡´ç‡™Ø ‡™™‡™∞‡™ø‡™∑‡™¶ | website=Gujarati Sahitya Parishad | url=http://www.gujaratisahityaparishad.com/prakashan/sarjako/savishesh/Savishesh-Dhansukhlal-Mehta.html | language=gu | access-date=2018-04-28}}</ref>
He died on August 29th, 1974{{where|date=June 2018}}.<ref name="Gujarati Sahitya Parishad"/>
==Works== Dhansukhlal Mehta wrote short stories, plays, literary criticism, book reviews, an autobiography, and humorous essays. According to [[Mansukhlal Jhaveri]], he was a pioneer of Gujarati short stories, and one of the first writers who depicted psychological conflicts in his characters.<ref name="JhaveriAkademi1978">{{cite book|author=Mansukhlal Maganlal Jhaveri|authorlink=Mansukhlal Jhaveri|title=History of Gujarati Literature|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DA0RAAAAMAAJ|year=1978|publisher=Sahitya Akademi|location=New Delhi|page=166}}</ref> His short stories dealt with contemporary family life.<ref>{{cite book|title=Maharashtra State Gazetteers: Language and literature|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lMBd9PJ1sCoC|accessdate=19 April 2018|year=1953|publisher=Directorate of Government Printing, Stationery and Publications|page=371}}</ref> However, according to the ''Encyclopedia of Indian Literature'', he couldn't develop the short stories as an art form.<ref name="Lal1992">{{cite book|author=Mohan Lal|title=Encyclopaedia of Indian Literature: Sasay to Zorgot|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KnPoYxrRfc0C&pg=PA4041|accessdate=22 April 2018|year=1992|publisher=Sahitya Akademi|location=New Delhi|isbn=978-81-260-1221-3|page=4041}}</ref> He began earnestly studying humorous writers of the West and wrote humorous essays, short stories, and sketches. In 1908, his short stories appeared in ''Jnanasudha'', a magazine edited by [[Ramanlal Desai]].<ref name="Datta1988">{{cite book|author=Amaresh Datta|title=Encyclopaedia of Indian Literature: Devraj to Jyoti|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zB4n3MVozbUC&pg=PA1602|accessdate=22 April 2018|year=1988|publisher=Sahitya Akademi|location=New Delhi|isbn=978-81-260-1194-0|page=1602}}</ref> [[Krishnalal Jhaveri]] wrote in ''Further Milestone in Gujarati Literature'', "Dhansukhlal Mehta never goes far afield in search of humor, but finds it in the actual work-a-day life around him. His art can be fully enjoyed only by a man who has lived in a small town in Gujarat, and as one read his works, he almost comes to love the everyday life of modern Gujarat in spite of its shortcomings."<ref name="Jhaveri1956">{{cite book|last=Jhaveri|first=Krishnalal Mohanlal |author-link=Krishnalal Jhaveri |title=Further milestones in GujarƒÅti literature|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rqxHAAAAMAAJ|year=1956|edition=2nd|publisher=Forbes Gujarati Sabha|location=Mumbai|pages=321}} {{PD-notice}}</ref>
His collections of short stories include ''Hu, Sarla ane Mitramandal'' (1920) and ''Asadharan Anubhav ane Biji Vato'' (1924).<ref name="George1992">{{cite book|author=K. M. George|authorlink=K. M. George (writer)|title=Modern Indian Literature, an Anthology: Surveys and poems|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m1R2Pa3f7r0C&pg=PA131|year=1992|publisher=Sahitya Akademi|location=New Delhi|isbn=978-81-7201-324-0|page=131}}</ref><ref name="NatarajanNelson1996">{{cite book|author1=Nalini Natarajan|author2=Emmanuel Sampath Nelson|title=Handbook of Twentieth-century Literatures of India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1lTnv6o-d_oC&pg=PA110|year=1996|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|location=London|isbn=978-0-313-28778-7|page=110}}</ref> In 1936, he co-wrote ''Ame Badha'' (lit. We All), a humorous autobiographical novel, with [[Jyotindra Dave]]. It was highly acclaimed and is widely regarded as one of the best humorous novels in Gujarati literature.<ref name="Menon1963">{{cite book|author=Rekha Menon|title=Cultural Profiles: Calcutta. Santiniketan|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1ntCAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=19 April 2018|year=1963|publisher=Inter-National Cultural Centre|page=35}}</ref><ref name="Datta1988"/> It was the second humorous novel in Gujarati, after ''[[Bhadrambhadra]]'' by [[Ramanbhai Neelkanth]]. According to Harshavadan Trivedi, it was the first co-written Gujarati novel.<ref name="Gujarati Sahitya Parishad"/>
In collaboration with [[Gulabdas Broker]], he wrote ''Dhumraser'', a dramatization of Broker's short story of the same name.<ref name="JhaveriAkademi1978"/><ref>{{cite book|title=Proceedings|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=scUtAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=19 April 2018|year=1957|page=288}}</ref> His selected humorous works were edited by [[Vinod Bhatt]] and published as ''Hasya Visesha: Dhansukhlal Mehta'' in 2017.<ref name="divyabhaskar 2017">{{cite web | title=‡™ß‡™®‡™∏‡´Å‡™ñ‡™≤‡™æ‡™≤ ‡™Æ‡™π‡´á‡™§‡™æ‡™®‡´Å‡™Ç ‡™π‡™æ‡™∏‡´ç‡™Ø-‡™ß‡™® | website=divyabhaskar | date=2017-10-08 | url=https://www.divyabhaskar.co.in/news/MAG-the-laughter-of-dhansukhlal-mehta-gujarati-news-5714962-NOR.html | language=gu | access-date=2018-04-21}}</ref>
==Awards== He was awarded the [[Ranjitram Suvarna Chandrak]] in 1940 for contributions to Gujarati literature. He received the [[Narmad Suvarna Chandrak]] in 1957 for ''Garib Ni Jhunpadi''.<ref name="Menon1963"/><ref name="Gujarati Sahitya Parishad"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{Internet Archive author|search=Dhansukhlal Maheta}} * [http://www.sahityasetu.co.in/issue29/varta.php ''Hu ane Sarla''] on Sahityasetu E-Journal.
{{Authority control}}
